topic.title: Configuring vCPU Scheduling and Priority
topic.shortdesc: You can assign the Linux scheduler and priority for non-boot virtual CPUs using an extra specification.

section.p: This extra specification applies to non-boot virtual CPUs, and is available only for flavors that define more than one virtual CPU. For the boot CPU, the Linux scheduler and priority are fixed to non-real-time, with a nice priority of 0.
For each additional virtual CPU, the available options are:

dd.p: Assigns a non-real-time scheduling policy with nice priority of 0.
Assigns a real-time, first-in-first-out policy with nice priority of 1‒99, specified in the associated VCPU Priority field.
Assigns a real-time, round-robin policy with nice priority of 1‒99, specified in the associated VCPU Priority field.

section.p: To add this extra spec to a flavor using the web administration interface, use the VCPU Scheduler Policy selection in the Create Flavor Extra Spec drop-down menu. To access this menu, see .

You can specify the scheduler policy and priority for non-boot virtual CPUs from the CLI using the hw:wrs:vcpu:scheduler parameter on the nova flavor-key command. This parameter accepts a semicolon-separated list of scheduler:priority:vcpus values as follows.

dd.p: The scheduler policy. One of other, fifo, or rr to indicate non real-time, FIFO, and Round Robin policies respectively.
The real-time scheduler priority. A value between 1 and 99.
A list of virtual CPUs as a comma-separated list (1,2,3) or a range specification (1-3). Virtual CPU number 0 refers to the boot virtual CPU and therefore cannot be used.

example.p: To set real-time schedulers and priorities on virtual CPU 1 (FIFO, 50) and virtual CPU 2 (Round Robin, 80):

codeblock.userinput: nova flavor-key flavor_name set hw:wrs:vcpu:scheduler fifo:50:1;rr:80:2

example.p: To set real-time Round Robin schedulers for three virtual CPU (Round Robin, 80):

codeblock.userinput: nova flavor-key flavor_name set hw:wrs:vcpu:scheduler rr:80:1-3
